eventName: Zoe and Cheryl Make The Cut
story:
We have decided to donate our long locks to The Little Princess Trust and raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support! We will both be cutting our hair to short pixie cuts (not quite braving the shave!) meaning between us we will be donating around 35‚Äù of hair!

Our family has truly felt the impact of Cancer over the years, all of Zoe‚Äôs grandparents lives have been touched by Cancer, and sadly two grandparents lost their lives to the disease. We also have had a special family friend diagnosed with Hodgkin‚Äôs Lymphoma who has undergone chemotherapy over the last year, thankfully they are now cancer free and awaiting further treatment to support their remission going forward!

The Little Princess Trust takes donations of human hair and transforms it into wigs, for children who have experienced hair loss from childhood cancer and other conditions. Each wig costs around ¬£550 to produce after donations are received, an expensive but incredible gift for these children.
Macmillan work hard across the UK to support those who experience a cancer diagnosis, as well as their loved ones, with emotional, financial and physical assistance. During the coronavirus pandemic Macmillan have continued to support people online and via their phone services, just ¬£50 can provide an hours online support service providing emotional and practical advice.

For us donating our hair is a thing we are able to choose to do to support these two causes, but for those who may receive our hair as a wig or experience support thanks to your donations there is no choice, we are incredibly passionate about supporting these two causes and hope you will help us in our aims to raise ¬£1000 to be shared between the two charities! If you choose to donate online your donation will go straight to Macmillan, however we will also collect cash donations which we will send to The Little Princess Trust alongside our hair! We know times are tough for a lot of people right now but any amount big or small will help us toward our goal, and we are incredibly thankful to each and every one of you for your donations!

story:
Tarsem Singh Chaggar was a dad, grandad, husband, brother, uncle, and hockey umpire.¬†

My dad lost his life after a short battle with cancer. Initially my dad was diagnosed with liver cancer which then spread to his lungs. By the time my dad was diagnosed he already had stage 4 cancer and was told by doctors that he would only have months to live.¬†My dad passed away 1 month after being diagnosed with cancer.¬†

It would have been nice to have given my dad a good send off, but life doesn't work that way. Cancer waits for no one.¬†

So if you can spare the cost of a drink or two towards my dad's collection we would be extremely grateful. All proceeds will go to Cancer Research UK.¬†¬†

Whilst my dad will not benefit from this collection towards cancer research, hopefully these funds will help someone else's dad, grandad, husband, brother, uncle. Someone else's loved ones.

I will leave this collection page open until 30th December 2020 which is the day my dad would have been 73 years old.

Please forward on this page and share it with others who had met my dad through his journey of life.

Hopefully one day we will be able to stop others suffering the same destiny as my dad.

Varinder Singh Chaggar (Tarsem's son) / The Chaggar family.

charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
After five years of conflict, most of the population in Yemen needs humanitarian assistance. They have a lack of basic healthcare, severe food shortages and limited clean water.  

CARE is focused on helping the most vulnerable people, through distributing food to families in need, and cash vouchers so that families can purchase for themselves the food they need.

Over a year of fighting and fuel shortages has destroyed water pipes and water pumping facilities, so CARE is rehabilitating water sources and providing water tanks so women and children can get safe drinking water without having to travel long distances.

CARE is also providing hygiene kits, paying special attention to womens and children's needs.

Thank you for reading. For more information please visit the dedicated Yemen Crisis page on CARE's website: www.careinternational.org.uk/emergencies/yemen-crisis
